Title: South from the Mouth of the Tees SPRING RESCHEDULED DATE
Summary:
Fancy a refreshing easier¬†stroll in the early spring in the ¬†Cleveland/North Yorkshire area?¬†¬†Well come over and walk away the blues on the Yorkshire beaches in¬†the company of OutdoorLads.
This walk is an easy linear route outing along the beach making use of the local train service to return
The views on the outward leg impress as the land¬†to the south rises from the sea¬†in impressive sandstone cliffs, further along this¬†section of the coast¬†to Skinningrove are the¬†highest cliffs on the east coast of England.
There is an opportunity to visit a ruined old church ruin to seek out the curious graves of the many who perished in the stormy waters and the pirate skull and cross bones etched on weathered grave stones.
The beaches visited on the walk at low tide are wide and easily shared with the horse riders, joggers and dog walkers.¬† There will be a pause at a midway point for the opportunity to go for food and a warm drink.
The destination is the charming¬†resort¬†of Saltburn-By-The-Sea and we will spend plenty of¬†time here to walk to the end¬†of the pier continue to Old Saltburn.
We will then either use the cliff lift to reach the higher level paths if open on the edge of the town and after a stop for photographs and pause at a nice bar before catching the train back to the start.
Photo Credits: The photographs used on this event page have been taken by OutdoorsLads leaders and permission to use in this publication and any future event pages or other releases.
Difficulty & Distance: 10.9km/6.8 miles one steep short climb

Title: Low Force and Middleton in Teesdale circular
Summary:
Total distance about 21.7kms (approx. 13.5 miles) with 400m (1,300 feet) ascent throughout. Approximately 5 1/2 hours, including lunch.
This walk includes sections that are relatively flat (riverside), a fairly challenging ascent, hillside with panoramic views, and the delightful town of Middleton-in-Teesdale. Although it is long and in places, strenuous, it's well worth the effort.
Starting from the High Force Hotel, we descend towards the River Tees. We cross the river and follow its course past the stunning Low Force waterfall. We then cross the river again via a narrow suspension bridge to reach Bowlees. This is where the ascent begins.
The next section of the walk passes through several farms, before crossing open hillside. As we begin to descend, we pass through woodland and follow Hudeshope Beck towards Middleton-in-Teesdale.
We cross the town, and there are several places to purchase refreshments, if required. We then cross the River Tees again, before following it's course back to the start point. This does mean repeating a small section of the riverside that we covered in the morning.
After the walk, there will be an optional trip to The High Force Hotel in Forest in Teesdale for anyone who would like a drink.
Please note that this walk does NOT include High Force waterfall. If you wish to visit this, tickets cost ¬£3.95 for adults. As winter access is 10am-3pm, you would need to visit before the 10:30 am walk start time. You can find further information on the
Raby website
.
Dogs: Well-behaved, under control dogs are welcome at this event.
Dogs should be kept on a lead whenever signposted, whenever we are in the vicinity of livestock, and at the event leader's request. Many stretches of this walk include sheep roaming. I would also note that there are quite a few up-and-over wall stiles towards the end of the walk, so you get a bit of an upper-body workout lifting your dogs over them. You'll need to make sure you're carrying sufficient extra water for your four-legged friend. We will meet natural water on parts of the walk. If you're unsure, contact the leader for guidance.
If the event is fully booked:
Please join the wait list as people frequently drop out during the week before an event, and you are likely to get a place on the walk.
If this is your first OutdoorLads walk event,
we‚Äôll make sure you feel welcome. Please
check out the My First Event page
, and don‚Äôt hesitate to drop me a message if you have questions or want to know more about this walk.

Title: Leeds Country Way from Thorner
Summary:
Friday is a lovely day to get out for a local walk. There are fewer people around and it‚Äôs easier to get parking.
This walk starts in Thorner, east of Leeds. We will mostly walk ¬†through fields, tracks and old railway lines, all flat, no hills.
The walk starts at 10:30am, but we will be having a midmorning and lunch break. I also like to stop and look at things along the way whether it is wildlife or unusual rock formations.
Well behaved dogs are welcome on this event. Please keep your dog on a lead and under control at all times.
Image credits : All images provided by the walk leader. OutdoorLads has permission to use them.
Difficulty & Distance: Flat, no hills

Title: Explore the Inns and Outs of Surgeons, Lawyers and Rogues
Summary:
THIS WALK IS ON A FRIDAY
This easy¬†linear walk¬†combines cultural sights and visits:
Hunterian Museum ‚Äì art and science of surgery with some fascinating exhibits.
Inns of Court at Lincoln‚Äôs Inn, Gray's Inn and Middle/Inner Temples.
St Bride‚Äôs - known as the journalist‚Äôs or wedding cake church.
2 Temple Place including its annual art exhibition.
The walk is inspired by my days as a young and eager legal beagle around Holborn, long long ago‚Ä¶
We will visit sights around Holborn, Chancery Lane and Fleet Street, and stop for stories following the footsteps of lawyers, surgeons and journalists.
For the indoor sights, I‚Äôll explain the highlights and we will have time to explore independently.¬†Each sight has free entry. We‚Äôll spend up to 1 hour at the Hunterian Museum and 30 minutes at 2 Temple Place.
Afterwards, please feel free to join for optional drinks at the Old Bank of England.
Don't waste that space!
The maximum group size is 20 for this event. This is due to it being an urban walk and bookings have been made for the indoor attractions.
Please only book if you know you can make it. If¬†your¬†plans change please free up the space for someone else.
Hunterian Museum
This is the headquarters of the Royal College of Surgeons, and the museum was reopened in 2023 following a ¬£4.6m redevelopment. It tells the story of the history of surgery to the present day, and you‚Äôll see England‚Äôs largest public display of human anatomy. We will have time to visit properly and are booked in.
The Inns of Court
All barristers must belong to an Inn of Court, and the plan is to walk through all four of them - Lincoln‚Äôs Inn, Gray‚Äôs Inn, Middle and Inner Temples. This is why the walk is on a weekday. We won‚Äôt be able to visit the chapels/great halls, but will pass the impressive barristers‚Äô chambers and gardens, which have the feel of historical Oxbridge colleges.
Chancery Lane and Fleet Street
There will be plenty of zig-zagging through the alleys and courtyards of legal London. We should be able to pass St Ethelburga‚Äôs Chapel, the old red brick Victorian Gothic Prudential Building and Dr Johnson‚Äôs House, where he compiled the Dictionary of the English Language. Fleet Street is the original home of London printing and the press.
St Bride‚Äôs Church
The reconstructed Christopher Wren church is known as the journalists‚Äô church. Its¬†spire may have inspired traditional tiered wedding cakes, and is only exceeded by St Paul‚Äôs Cathedral in the City. We may be able to see the memorial to the first known victim of Jack the Ripper and visit the crypt with its Roman pavement.
Two Temple Place
Built for Lord Astor (who was one of the richest men in the world) as his office around 1895, with neo-Gothic wooden carvings and windows. It opens for an annual exhibition. This year‚Äôs is ‚ÄúWeight of Being: Vulnerability, Resilience and Mental Health in Art‚Äù which we are booked in for and will visit.
‚Äî-
Dogs - sorry, no dogs are permitted at these sights.
No toilets at start. Toilets at Hunterian Museum before lunch, possible cafes at lunch and near end at 2 Temple Place.
The
route
can be seen on the
OS Map -
Click here
- which is included for guidance only.
New Members
New members are very welcome. Please message me if you have any questions or concerns before the day.
Whilst we are a very open and welcoming group, if you wish, we may be able to organise an existing member to buddy up with you before or on the day. Do also feel free to arrive early as I‚Äôm always around much earlier than the start time.
All leader's own images - with permission for OutdoorLads to use and reuse
Difficulty & Distance: 4.4 miles - flat walk with sightseeing and visits to indoor attractions

Title: 1000m Lords Over Thor
Summary:
My Lord! Your challenge is to conquer the peaks of the Manifold Valley, adding up to 1000 metres of ascent over the day. Along the way you will see much superb scenery of the White Peak, limestone shining in the spring light. The challenge culminates above Thor's cave, marking your Lordship over the whole valley!
This difficult hill route follows many steep slopes, making use of access land and permissive paths at times, as well as scrambly banks, so you will need to be comfortable with this kind of walk. We aim to cover the three tops of Wetton Hill, (319m 355m 328m), Ecton Hill (369m), Ecton South top (360m), Dale above Sugar Load (325m), Ossoms Hill (334m) and Thor's Height (294m). The rewards for this are that you will have accomplished an amazing challenge and experienced some unbeatable and incredible views of Thor's cave and the Manifold Valley. The walk southwards on a hidden route towards the impending Thor's cave is particularly spectacular.
Ecton Hill at the north end of our route was the centre of historic copper mines and a wealthy earner for local miners. There are information boards near the mine remains. We'll also see the small cave at Wettonmill, where there is a tearoom, which we will pass mid-afternoon.
From Ossom's Hill we head onward with giant Thor looming ahead, cross the Manifold river and head up a path with a long flight of steps. The cave itself is huge, slippy and scrambly. After the cave, we will go further to circle the giant's lair and come out on top, above the cave, for all round views of the valley.
This is as difficult as hill walks get and is pretty much the same as a mountain walk, and certainly good preparation for one, We may adjust the walk according to weather conditions, and there will be an opportunity to miss a peak if you're tired, but please come ready for a challenge. A recent OutdoorLads hill walk would be excellent preparation!
If bad weather, we may shorten the route to 500m ascent, but will still include Thor's cave. Note that if you just wanted to see Thor's cave without the rest of the challenge, you might be better choosing a hillwalk focused on that alone, which is offered by OutdoorLads leaders regularly, if not often.
Well behaved dogs who are fit enough to manage this challenge are welcome to accompany us on this walk.
Note:
If there are no places left on this event, join the waiting list, as people frequently drop out during the week before an event, and you are likely to get a place.
Want to keep in¬†touch with what's going on¬†in the Midlands / ODL Central Region?
Join our
Central Region Telegram Chat Group
, or the more more local
East Midlands Telegram Chat Group
and bookmark our upcoming events list via the short link:
https://outdoorlads.events/central
Pictures: taken by Outdoorlads members, free to reuse.
Difficulty & Distance: 1000m ascent over around 10.5miles  / 17km with some steep terrain

Title: Hull parkrun
Summary:
Joining us for the Hull Social or just in the area anyway? ¬†Why not join OutdoorLads at Hull parkrun?
This is one of a number of events we have organised over the weekend of the
Hull Social
.
If you are planning to attend the walk or bouldering event today, we have allowed sufficient time to get to either of these once you have completed the run
About parkrun
While parkrun is a public event, if joining as part of OutdoorLads please do join this event page (and drop off it if you can no longer attend) so the leader knows who to expect and who to inform if there is a change of plans..
The course is 5000m (5km) long. This has been accurately measured by parkrun with a professional measuring wheel. It's run on paths and grass, although some sections of the course do accumulate mud, leaves and puddles after rain.¬† Dependent on availability, marshals will be at key sections of the course, or signs will be in place.
The important bit... This is about personal goals. You run/walk at your own pace, don't be scared that you may be slower than other people. Some walk, some run, some jog, some do a combination of all three.
To take part in a parkrun and get your official time,
you will need to have
registered
to receive your all important barcode
.
You will need to bring this barcode with you either printed or on your phone.
Parkrun events are run nationwide and indeed internationally, so once you're signed up you can attend anywhere.¬† If you don't have a barcode you can still run but won't get a time.
Please see under Location for meeting plans.
The event link is here:
https://www.parkrun.org.uk/hull/
Dogs
parkrun allow one dog per person on a short lead (not extending). ¬†Running with more than one dog, extending leads or waist leads are not permitted at parkrun events. ¬†As a third party event, OutdoorLads does not have any control over this.
OutdoorLads Running Groups
If you want to join the Outdoorlads' national group on the parkrun website, on your parkrun account select Profile, then groups and type "Outdoorlads (UK)" and click the Join button.
You may also wish to sign up to the
Strava OutdoorLads running club:
https://www.strava.com/clubs/439735
Photos by an OutdoorLads leader (OutdoorWill) and used with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Run or walk at your own pace

Title: BIRMINGHAM Indoor Climbing - MONDAY - Beginners
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads for an evening at Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre.
*** Beginner (supervised) events are not offered every week ***
If you have never climbed before (or need a refresher on the basics), then this BEGINNERS EVENT is ideal for you! We will happily show you the ropes & teach you everything you need to know to climb safely!
Event pages are split into
BEGINNER & EXPERIENCED.
Please ensure you sign up to the correct event as we can only supervise two beginners at once per leader.
This event is for beginner climbers (those needing to be supervised) only!
If you are competent with how to tie in & belay (safely & confidently), then you will need to
sign up to the accompanying experienced (independent climber) event
instead.
Bouldering
- Most of us do roped climbing, but if you prefer to do bouldering, you can sign yourself in & go bouldering (unsupervised) instead of, or as well as, roped climbing. Please meet the leader & the group at the start though; some others might wish to do bouldering too!
Please note that we will not teach lead climbing or lead belaying on this event -
we would suggest having some
lessons in Lead Climbing
by a qualified member of staff if this is something you're interested in pursuing!
If the event is full, please join the waiting list as you may be able to get a space closer to the event date.
If you are subsequently unable to attend, please cancel off the event. Spaces for beginners are limited & 'no-shows' are frustrating for the leader & other attendees.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
Indoor climbing centres offer the challenges of climbing that you'll find on natural rock crags - simply indoors! It's a fun way to stay fit, make new friends & develop your climbing skills.
Climbing
- Unlike Indoor Bouldering there is a certain amount of skill to be mastered, such as tying in knots & belaying a partner, as well as the climbs being higher than in bouldering.¬†If you are new to climbing (or would like a refresher), there are plenty of top-rope routes to choose from after learning the essential climbing & safety techniques with one of our friendly, experienced climbing leaders.
Bouldering
-¬†Instead of tackling long high routes, the 'problems' (as they are referred to) are shorter & focus on technique, balance, body positioning & sometimes power.¬†With the different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, so it‚Äôs excellent (but not necessarily easier) for newcomers.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre

It even features one of the few indoor 'Yorkshire VS cracks' in the country, to test your jamming skills. The¬†bouldering rooms are just as interesting as its climbing routes, over 200 bouldering problems have been organised into graded circuits to provide something for everyone.

Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre

Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre

It even features one of the few indoor 'Yorkshire VS cracks' in the country, to test your jamming skills. The¬†bouldering rooms are just as interesting as its climbing routes, over 200 bouldering problems have been organised into graded circuits to provide something for everyone.

Title: Wick and Dyrham
Summary:
Join Andrew for a walk around Wick, Doynton, Hinton and Dyrham. The walk is easily accessed from the M4 and for those coming from Bristol, Bath and the surrounding area. We will be walking on the established Monarch's Way and Cotswold Way for part of the walk as well as passing through some beautiful villages and skirting around the edge of the Golden Valley Nature Reserve. There will be an optional pub stop at the end of the walk.
Photos taken by ODL members MEW and PL1957 and permission is granted to OutdoorLads for further use.
Dogs
are welcome to join us on this event but we do ask the following:
Please appreciate the fact that not everyone is a dog owner or lover- especially when we stop to eat
Please ensure you adhere to the Countryside Code at all times - see
(Keeping Dogs Under Effective Control)
If your dog is uncontrolled and strays in open land frightening other animals or livestock, the leader is supported by the OutdoorLads board of trustees to ask you to leave the event as this is not acceptable behaviour
We cannot guarantee that this route is dog friendly - there may be styles to carry your dog across.
Your dog needs to have the stamina to keep up with the group. This may be an issue on hot days.
Difficulty & Distance: 10.5 miles in about 6 hours inc breaks

Title: Top o' th' Calder. Todmorden.
Summary:
We will explore the upper extreme of the Calder Valley between Todmorden and Cliviger.
The infamous River Calder ("violent water") is mostly a culverted stream at this stage of its life.
We will pass close to its source at Heald Moor (the source two river Calders!).
The valley here is at its steepest, bleakest, quietest and remotest. It has its own unique beauty in comparison to further down the catchment.
We will have hills, great views and water! The walk is approximately 10 miles long with a 580 meter total ascent
We will call at The Bridestones, approximately 430m above sea level. They were formerly the abode of druids and the site of ritualistic and sacrificial ceremonies. It was probably named after Bridia, a Brigantes deity. Legend also suggests weddings took place on the moor giving the "Great Bride Stone" and smaller "Groom Stone" their name.
We will follow the Calder way To Pudsey Clough and straddle the Lancashire borders before heading up and along the opposite side of the valley by Dobroyd Castle, an important, historic building built in 1866 and continue back to Todmorden.
This is a dog friendly walk, so well behaved dogs welcome. There are a few stiles on a small section, so bigger dogs might need extra hands.
We will finish in The Golden Lion for a great selection of beers and Thai food.
Image / photo credits:
All leader's own images - OutdoorLads has permission to use and them.

please
join the waiting list as people frequently drop out during the week before an event and you are likely to get a place on the walk.

Summary:
Join us for a joint cycle with

- a short (37 mile) winter ride from Glasgow into the Renfrewshire countryside.
Outward route through Newton Mearns to Malletsheugh, cross-country to Neilston before climbing over to Howwood.
Return route via Johnstone and Paisley.
We should be finished by early afternoon, but bring lights just in case.

Come and join me for a relaxed, easy circular walk in the beautiful Marbury area.
We head to Marbury to enjoy the big views from the top of the hill, and a gentle stroll along the canal, through several open fields, and around Marbury Big Mere Lake. The walk will finish at Marbury Church.
This easy, casual leisure walk is ideal if you‚Äôre new to OutdoorLads, or if you‚Äôre simply looking to meet new guys and make friends in a relaxed setting.
We‚Äôll stop at the Willeymoor Lock Tavern for lunch, then finish back at the car park, with the option of a refreshing drink or meal at the pub afterwards.

Title: Explore Wales‚Äô Largest Ancient Woodland (located between Bristol and Cardiff)
Summary:
Going through mixed woodland and seeing lots of bluebells, we will pass the highest point in Wentwood (309m) on our way to the ¬†Curley Oak (close to the most recent (1996) execution), then to the Foresters Oaks, where twice yearly Law Courts were held, with the last offender hanged in 1829.
We will then go past the Wentwood Reservoir and up to the summit of Gray Hill (273m) where we will find a Megalithic alignment of standing stones, stone circle and ¬†neolithic or Bronze age enclosure.
We will then head back to the car park via the ‚ÄúFive Lanes‚Äù crossing, where it is possible to head in 10 different directions, which was the scene of Gwent‚Äôs biggest ever illegal rave (3000 people, for 36 hours) in 2007.
The area is home to thousands of wildlife species and we may be lucky enough to spot wild deer.
Dogs:
Dogs under close control are welcome on this event, so long as owners are able to lift them over locked gates and high stiles.

Difficulty & Distance: 12km (7.5 miles) in 4.5 hours

Title: Ben Tirran via Lochs Brandy and Wharral
Summary:
A joint hill-walk with the Gay Outdoor Club
Join us for a rewarding day in the Angus Glens as we explore the high plateau above Glen Clova, taking in two beautiful corrie lochs on our way to the broad summit of
Ben Tirran
. This route blends dramatic scenery with steady, achievable climbing, making it a fantastic outing for walkers who enjoy big views, good company, and a sense of journey.
We begin in Glen Clova, following the well‚Äëmade path that rises steadily toward Loch Brandy, a classic corrie loch cradled beneath steep, sweeping slopes. After enjoying the loch‚Äôs amphitheatre-like setting, we continue upward onto the plateau, where the landscape opens out into wide, rolling moorland.
From here, we make a gentle ascent to the summit of the Corbett, Ben Tirran at 896m, a broad, quiet top with expansive views across the Angus hills and out toward the Cairngorms. Our descent leads us past the tranquil waters of Loch Wharral, a lesser‚Äëknown gem tucked into the hillside, before we re-join lower paths and return to Glen Clova.
We will follow the route described on
WalkHighlands
.
Dogs:
The walk is suitable for dogs, which must be kept under control at all times, particularly near livestock.
Photos:
Taken on a previous walk up Ben Tirran with GOC in December 2012

Title: A Trio of Reservoirs in the Springtime
Summary:
An invigorating springtime
SUNDAY
Spectacular Walking and Picnic Event !
Welcome to a Trio of Reservoir Walk! This OutdoorLads walk will take us on a refreshing springtime stroll around all three large reservoirs:¬†Entwistle, Wayoh and Jumbles. A perfect way to end the week with a, 'good ol' "leg stretcher", and a chance to enjoy the fresh feeling of spring !
There will be a mixture of terrains starting with a relatively leisurely flat walk around Entwistle, before the more challenging Wayoh and Jumbles, being completed in one lengthy loop.
We will stop off for a while to rest and enjoy the views, before we head off for our picnic at Jumbles. There will also be extra coffee breaks and photo opportunities throughout the day.
The Jumbles Reservoir is a heavily modified, high alkalinity, shallow reservoir in North West England. It lies in Jumbles Country Park, in the valley of Bradshaw Brook, partly in the Metropolitan Borough of Bolton, Greater Manchester, and partly in Blackburn with Darwen, Lancashire
After passing the water plantation on Wayoh on our home stretch, we will walk along the hillside paths ‚Äì uphill, before reaching the final stretch of the walk which takes us back via the ‚ÄòStrawbury Duck‚Äô country inn, and down back to the car park. The Strawbury Duck is approx. 5-10 mins from the car park.
Please message the event leader if you have any questions prior to the event.

Title: Bristol Board Games Sunday Social
Summary:
Join us for a Sunday afternoon socialising and playing games
Time to bring out your competitive side with a fun afternoon socialising with other Outdoorlads in¬†Bristol's lovely Chance & Counters games cafe on Gloucester Road.
The cafe has over 850 new and old games to choose from so there should be something for everyone (although I could quite happily play UNO all day). To keep your game-playing energy up the caf√© serves food, soft drinks and alcohol. We usually have lunch there and then start playing (but there's no obligation to eat, if you don't want to!).
I've booked a table at 1pm for eight for four hours. It's ¬£8 each (paid to the cafe at the end of the session). We're a friendly bunch and it's always a good laugh. If you're new to Outdoorlads it's a great way to hang out with and get to know other members but in a cosy indoor setting.

Title: BikeOut Festival 2026
Summary:
You are cordially invited to join the UKs first queer festival of the bicycle! ¬†This will be run in conjunction with a whole range of other LGBT bike groups and is supported by Rapha and All In Racing. ¬†There will be a whole range of cycles offered across the weekend - road and gravel are the name of the game. ¬†There will also be some social events across the weekend, so it should be ¬†a great way to get some miles in and meet some new people. ¬†They plan to cater for most abilities - if you are used to cycling at least 40km on a road/gravel mix then there should be a ride for you. ¬†If you are a super-fast road demon then that's no problem either - I am reliably informed there will be some advanced level rides too.
This event is being run by the BikeOut team, but OutdoorLads are an invited member group. ¬†You will, however, have to register directly with the festival itself in order to attend the events: you can do so at this link
https://bikeout.cc/
You can also sign up here, on the outdoorlads website, so that we know who is coming from OutdoorLads and to help co-ordinate some social events over the course of the weekend.
There are cycles planned for both the Saturday and Sunday of the weekend. ¬†There will also be an introductory, social event on the Friday night.
Bike hire is possible from AlpKit in Hathersage - please contact and arrange this early.
There are lots of accommodation options in the area -the bikeout website has details of them. ¬†I, however, will be staying at North Lees campsite -
https://www.peakdistrict.gov.uk/visiting/things-to-do/camping/camping-northlees
This has both pods and camping pitches, and has the advantage of being the base for the rapha team for the weekend and also the planned site of a Saturday night pizza/bbq event. ¬†The website says that you can take a campervan, but they don't have hard parking or electric hook-up - you need to park it in a standard parking space.
Difficulty & Distance: There will be a range of rides on offer, so you can choose from easier to harder

Title: Chirk & River Ceiriog Walk ‚Äì Fall in Love with the Views!
Summary:
Don't worry if the event is full. Pop yourself on the waitlist and you'll get a place if someone drops out - People often change plans nearer the time and there's a high chance you'll get a place on the event.
Celebrate the weekend of love with a scenic ramble through the charming landscapes of Chirk and the River Ceiriog. This 6.5-mile circular route is the perfect way to share the outdoors with friends old and new‚Äîbecause nothing says "Valentine's" like falling head over heels for stunning scenery!
Our walk begins near Chirk and takes us through a mix of open pastures, peaceful woodland, and riverside paths. Expect a few steep slopes and stiles along the way.
We'll start by wandering through the historic grounds of Chirk Castle, a place that has stood the test of time‚Äîjust like true love. From there, we join the legendary Offa's Dyke Path, where sweeping views of the Ceiriog Valley will make you stop and stare (and maybe snap a romantic selfie or two).
As we continue, the route leads us to the impressive Chirk Aqueduct and Viaduct, marvels of engineering that bridge more than just rivers‚Äîthey connect landscapes and stories. And if that's not enough to make your heart flutter, the tranquil riverside paths and rolling pastures will surely do the trick.
This is Daniel‚Äôs assessment walk, so Daniel will be leading. Mark will be at the back, there purely for moral support (and assessment).

Title: Leigh to Irlam -GM17
Summary:
This is stage 17 of 20 on the Greater Manchester Ringway, a 200 mile (322km) walking trail exploring all 10 boroughs of Greater Manchester. You can find out more about it
here
.
This section of the trail explores the Wigan and Salford Mosslands. This peaceful area, formerly used for peat extraction, has benefited from extensive regeneration and is home to more than 150 bird species, rare mammals, amphibians, dragonflies, butterflies and plants.
Highlights include:
Hope Carr Nature Reserve, which boasts a complex array of wetland habitats
Footpaths along the valley of the tranquil River Glaze (or Glazebrook)
Views of three historic country homes (Light Oaks Hall, Little Woolden Hall and Great Woolden Hall)
The 115-hectare Little Woolden Moss nature reserve, restored by Lancashire Wildlife Trust and now home to plant species such as sphagnum moss and cottongrass, birds of prey and ground-nesting birds, and animals such as the common lizard and bog bush cricket
Irlam Station, with its delightful linear park, restored signal box and friendly cafe.
Note that parts of the trail may be damp, muddy and slippery at any time of year and especially after periods of wet weather.
This is a linear walk
. See the options in the location details below.

Title: LONDON  BOULDERING (SUNDAY) + Optional Pub visit. üòÉ

Come and join us for a chilled and fun Sunday bouldering session!
Bouldering is a form of climbing where instead of long high routes, the ‚Äòproblems‚Äô as they are referred to, tend to be lower/shorter and focus on technique, balance, body positioning and sometimes power. Because of this different emphasis, bouldering doesn‚Äôt have the hassle of climbing with ropes, harnesses and belaying, which makes the activities excellent for newcomers to the sport. With climbs of various grades suitable for complete beginners to seasoned pros, you decide how much you wish to challenge yourself.
If you have not visited the Stronghold Centre before, it is recommended that you

All those attending must also be aware of the centre‚Äôs own T&C‚Äôs etc. You are responsible at all times for your own safety, actions and involvement. As such you should use your own judgement in taking up advice given either by OutdoorLads volunteers or other experienced climbers.

Title: Hulltural Tour
Summary:
Following the
Hull social
, I will be hosting a short cultural bimble around Hull taking in some of the cultural areas of the City.
We will meet at the Queen Victoria statue (Queen Victoria Square) - the location of Hull City Hall, Hull maritime museum (closed for refurbishment) and the Ferens Art Gallery, which hosted the acclaimed Turner prize.
We will start with a quick tour of the gallery before heading to the old town cobbled streets museums quarter, where we will stay an hour or so visiting:
Hull Street life (transport museum across the ages and features a 1950s street scene).
Wilberforce (discover the house where the MP for Hull who campaigned to abolish slavery lived and an impressive museum).
Hull museum ( take a walk through time from the wooly mammoth and end towards more modern times).
Following a tour of the museums we can make a stop at the sailmakers pub for a quick drink before continuing down the high street and either head to the Deep to visit the Penguins and Sharks (tickets for the deep are ¬£23/person) or Hull Minster to tour one of England's oldest and biggest Parish churches built in the 1300s - free admission if it's open).
Images are taken by Andy Watts or available via free image sites and copyright free.
Difficulty & Distance: Gentle walk along flat paths.

Title: Ay Up Me Duck - Two Parks and a Brewery
Summary:
This 16 km (10-mile) route begins at Little Chester near the site of a small Roman fort and town known as Derventio. It takes in Darley Park and Allestree Park to the north of Derby city centre, and we visit the Shiny Brewery Tap at Little Eaton where award winning beers are created. Non-alcoholic beverages are available.
At the start of the walk we cross the river at Handyside Bridge, also known as Derwent Bridge, built in 1878 for the Great Northern Railway. The railway line closed in 1968 and it was converted to a foot bridge in 1976.
On the western side of the river we walk past Derby Rowing Club, formed in 1857.
Darley Park
is home to the largest collection of Hydrangeas in Britain, and the third largest in the world. First planted in 1984 it now has over 400 different types, however, there won't be many blooms to see in March.
We will pause to take refreshments at Darley Park Tearooms.
The settlement of
Darley Abbey
dates back to the medieval era, when it was the site of an Augustinian monastery. In the 18th century, the Evans family developed their planned industrial mill village to service their Boar's Head Mill, one of the first water-powered mills at the beginning of the Industrial Revolution.
We cross over the busy A6 through the suburb of Allestree and into Allestree Park from where we get great views into the Derwent valley. From here we continue uphill to Quarndon, one of the wealthiest villages in the area.
From Bunkers Hill we head back down into the valley, back across the A6, past St Alkmund's Church and over Duffield Bridge towards Little Eaton.
Shiny Brewery was established in 2012 as a small-scale cask brewery operation in the beer garden at the back of the Furnace Inn pub in Derby. It moved to Little Eaton in 2015 and invested in making better beer which is now available nation-wide in cask, keg and cans as well as from the taproom.
The Shiny Tap
also sells pizzas if you fancy one in the afternoon as well as, or instead of, a packed lunch.
From Little Eaton we cross underneath the A38 ring road on the Derwent Valley Heritage Way and back through Darley Park and Little Chester to the start point.
Dogs:
Well behaved dogs are welcome but owners must ensure they are kept under control at all times.
Note:
If there are no places left on this event, join the waiting list, as people frequently drop out during the week before an event, and you are likely to get a place.
Want to keep in¬†touch with what's going on¬†in the Midlands / ODL Central Region?
Join our
Central Region Telegram Chat Group
, or the more more local
East Midlands Telegram Chat Group
and bookmark our upcoming events list via the short link:
https://outdoorlads.events/central
Difficulty & Distance: Distance 16¬†km (10¬†miles). Total ascent 196 m (643¬†feet). Approximately 5.5¬†hours. Some paths are uneven and may be boggy in wet conditions.

Title: FRIDAY FELLS - The "Other" Borrowdale
Summary:
Join us for the first Friday Fells of 2026 - ¬†a 10¬†mile circular mountain¬†walk (600m ascent) in the Lake District's most recent extension.
The Lake District National Park was extended by about 3% in 2016, adding roughly 188 square miles primarily to its eastern and southern fringes. ¬†This walk takes in part of that extension, Borrowdale - not the famous one near Keswick we all know and love; ¬†the other one... new to the Lake District.
We'll start the walk from Low Borrowdale Car Park off the A685 Tebay-Kendal road just south of Tebay village (M6 J38). ¬†At this point, we'll be right next to the M6 and the West Coast Main Line with cars and trains rushing through the Lune Gorge between Scotland and London, but we'll soon be transported into a secret valley that time and almost everyone else seems to have forgotten. ¬†We'll start with a steep climb onto Whinfell Ridge, with amazing views south to Morecambe Bay, west to the Lake District fells, north to the Pennines and the Eden Valley and east to the Howgills. We'll follow the faint path along the undulating ridge to the A6, before dropping into the valley for a peaceful and easy walk back to the start.
At the end of the day, we'll go for an optional drink at
The Cross Keys Inn
in Tebay.
You can find the planned route
here
, though we may vary this depending on the abilities and ambitions of the group and weather conditions.
Event full?
Please join the waiting list. ¬†Places usually open up as the event gets nearer and, where necessary, we try to add additional leaders to increase the numbers, so you are highly likely to get a place.
New Members:
Please feel free to join this as your first OutdoorLads event, do note that this walk is likely to require some experience.¬†If you have any questions then feel free to message me, or go to the "My First Event" section under "About Us".
Is it¬†dog friendly?
Well-trained dogs are welcome but please note and abide by the
Countryside Code
. Please also remember¬†not everyone loves¬†dogs as much as you do so please be mindful of other members.
Image
/
photo
credits
:¬† All images (c) JPV with permission for OutdoorLads to use and reuse.
Difficulty & Distance: For a mountain walk, a relatively modest amount of ascent and distance

Title: Bagshot Heath And Swinley Forest Forage
Summary:
A
10-mile circular winter wander
through
Swinley Forest and Bagshot Heath
, where tall pines creak overhead and sandy paths crunch satisfyingly underfoot. This route mixes wide forest tracks with open, windswept heath, offering big skies, quiet corners, and plenty of space to stomp out the winter blues. Bracing, a little wild, and best enjoyed with rosy cheeks and a well-earned beer or hot drink at the end.
The route is essentially a loop around Swinley Forest, which is one of the most popular areas of wild open space in the Bracknell/Camberley area. This is a popular leisure area so no doubt there will be other walkers, families and mountain bikers around, however we will also take a few quieter paths to get away from the masses.
There are no stiles on the entire route and the walk is suitable for
dogs
.
We will commence walking through Bagshot Village, taking Church Lane past St Anne's church and Vicarage Road which leads to a 2km dead straight track into Swinley Forest, past open areas and pine trees. We continue North until the end of the forest area and then West to the LookOut Discovery Centre where we will stop for lunch. After lunch we then go South via the Windsor RRide and the Lower Star Post and when we reach Saddleback Hill go East back towards Bagshot.
The route can be found
here
:
Here is some of the features of the route:
Swinley Forest
is a large, tranquil woodland in Berkshire, dominated by tall Scots pine and criss-crossed by wide, sandy tracks. It sits on the edge of Windsor Great Park, an area with deep royal heritage, and was once part of the historic Windsor Forest that served the Crown for centuries as hunting and woodland estate. Today, Swinley Forest is managed for both forestry and recreation, giving it a spacious, open feel with plenty of light filtering through the trees. Popular with walkers, runners, and cyclists, it offers gentle gradients, peaceful routes, and a sense of stepping into a quietly regal landscape just beyond the surrounding towns.
Bagshot Heath
is an area of lowland heathland in Surrey and Berkshire, England, historically part of the wider Windsor Forest and Great Park. It‚Äôs known for its sandy soils, open heath, and wildlife, including heathland birds and reptiles. Much of it is now protected or managed for conservation, recreation, and military use.
Bagshot village
is a historic village in Surrey, located near the border with Berkshire. It developed as a coaching stop on the main London‚ÄìExeter road and later grew with the arrival of the railway. Prince Edward lives with his family at Bagshot Park, a large Grade II‚Äìlisted mansion set in about 51 acres.
Difficulty & Distance: 10 mile moderate length walk mainly flat on good paths with minimal inclines and ascent of just 150 meters.

Title: Manchester Board Game Night
Summary:
Join us for a fun evening of games at an easily accessible and excellent board game cafe in Manchester.
Games vary based on what those attending would like to play, but we mostly choose easy to learn games that anyone, from brand new players to seasoned veterans, can easily pick up and enjoy.
There's a cover charge of ¬£8 per person for the full 3 hours. This is paid separately at the cafe
.
If you're new to OutdoorLads, you're especially welcome. It's a great way to meet and get to know people in a fun and relaxed environment.
Images created by event leader, used with their permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Social

Title: BIG Spring Camp 2026
Summary:
üèîÔ∏è BIG Spring Camp 2026: The 20th Anniversary Blowout!
Get ready to pitch up, dress up, and celebrate!
BIG Spring Camp
is back for 2026, and it‚Äôs a massive one‚Äîwe are officially
20 years old!
We‚Äôre returning to our stunning home in the heart of Eryri (Snowdonia). Imagine a weekend with full use of a rugby club base, surrounded by dramatic peaks, adrenaline-pumping adventures, and a few hundred of your newest best friends. Whether you want to conquer a mountain, get wet in a gorge, or just take it easy, this is the weekend to do it.
üéÇ Twenty Years of OutdoorLads
Since 2006, we‚Äôve been getting folks outdoors, and we aren't slowing down. Expect some special 20th-anniversary surprises throughout the weekend. We‚Äôve had two decades of mud, sweat, and beers‚Äîlet's make this the biggest celebration yet! Lots of surprises and we're changing many things up this year, including the activities on offer, ¬†as we make this THE one to remember for the next 20 years.. ¬†We can't think of a better place to be to celebrate 20 years of OutdoorLads!
üõ∂ The Main Attractions: Activities
From high-octane thrills to low-level wanders, we have it all. While the 2026 schedule is still being polished, here is a flavour of what will be on the menu:
The Professional Thrills:
Expect favourites like White Water Rafting, Coasteering, Zip Lines, and Mine Exploration. We partner with local experts to get your heart racing.
The Volunteer Legends:
Our amazing leaders will be heading out for some scrambling, hiking, cycling, mountain biking, climbing, or just a stroll to the local villages.
On-Site Shenanigans:
Games, challenges and silly fun - ¬†there‚Äôs plenty to keep you busy while you're on site!
Activity bookings will open up in a few weeks. Keep your eyes on your inbox after signing up!
üç∫ The Clubhouse & The Outdoor Inn
The clubhouse is our hub. By day, it‚Äôs a spot for coffee and watching people tumble off inflatables. By night, it‚Äôs a legendary party space. Last year our Saturday evening fancy dress party had us Step Back in Time. Where will 2026 take us..? ü™©
In the clubhouse you'll also find the facilities like bathrooms and showers, and generally where you'll find the event organisers if you have any questions.
The Outdoor Inn is our more quiet bar area, located around the back of the clubhouse in a big marquee. A good place to chill out, play some board games, or just catch up with that guy you haven't seen since this time last year!
üçî Food & Fuel
No need to survive on cereal bars alone. You can do it yourself by your tent (just keep those stoves and BBQs off the grass!). Or, you can use our clubhouse catering. We'll have a range of hot breakfasts, delicious evening meals, snacks and grab-and-go packed lunches for your adventures.
‚õ∫ Tents & Campervans
Tents:
Most folks bring their own, but if you're new to camping, we have a
limited number of
tents to hire
for a small fee.
Campervans/Caravans:
Space is extremely limited (approx. 20 spots). These must be pre-booked and tend to sell out in minutes. So, set your alarms for the booking date, which will be advised in due course - likely to be late February. As this is a rugby club, there's no EHU or waste disposal facilities.
üìú Rules to Keep Everybody Happy
The
OutdoorLads Code of Conduct
applies to everyone at all times.
Respect the grass:
This is a rugby club first and foremost. So, no glass, no dogs, ¬†no BBQs/stoves on the grass, and no open fires (other than the 'official' campfire).
Drugs:
Zero tolerance to illegal substances. Anyone suspected of having drugs will be asked to leave immediately.
Smoking and vaping:
Not permitted anywhere in the clubhouse or marquee.
Quiet Time:
Noisy fun in the bars; quiet in the camping fields between
23:00 and 07:00
. Tents have zero soundproofing.
Spacing:
2 meters between tents for fire safety.
Waste:
Sort your recycling before binning - this is the law in Wales. Don't leave any rubbish lying around. Large items like broken camping chairs need to go home with you to be disposed of.
Vehicles:
No cars outside the permitted car park areas. No EV charging on site.
Day visitors
: There are no day passes available. You must be booked on to this event to attend BIG Spring Camp for any duration of time.
New to OutdoorLads?
: If you're new (or relatively new) to OutdoorLads and worried about not knowing anybody when you get to BIG Spring Camp, then worry not! You can join one of our smaller new member camps, led by some of our amazing, approachable volunteers, who'll help introduce you to others on the first evening. You'll camp together with other new members, and have use of an event shelter for socialising near your tent. Just makes that intro to the event and to OutdoorLads that much easier! We'll make details available nearer the time.
Spread the cost:
If you would prefer to pay in monthly instalments, please
contact the office team
(or
raise a support ticket
) and we can discuss the options available to you. There will be additional terms and conditions to agree to before you commit. You won't pay anything extra to pay in instalments. The full cost must have been paid by 1st May 2026.
OutdoorLads Foundation:
Don't forget that full and concession members who may be experiencing¬†physical, mental or financial challenges can apply for support with the costs of events themselves, or associated spend, to enable fuller participation. Further details on the
Foundation pages on our website
.
Photos:
Provided by OutdoorLads members and volunteers, and used with permission.
Dogs:
This event is not suitable for dogs and they are not permitted on site at any time.
Difficulty & Distance: BSC is as easy or hard as you make it - plenty for everyone!

Title: BSC26: Rent a Tent
Summary:
This is for renting a tent at
BIG Spring Camp 2026.
If you're travelling light, you may like to borrow a tent from OutdoorLads. If that's the case, just sign up to this event page, and we'll provide you with a tent when you register on arrival.
For ¬£15¬†we will provide you a tent and a sleeping mat.
You will need to bring a sleeping bag
or other sleeping medium.¬†You will need to collect the tent on arrival at registration - it is very easy to put up. Whilst it is a two man tent, be aware that is actually is quite small and if there are two people in it, it will be extremely cosy!
At the end of the event, all we ask is that you please take the tent down and pack it away, and return it to the reception area where you poicked it up from.
This is real convenience so take advantage and make your BIG Spring Camp that little bit easier!
Photos kindly supplied by and used with permission from OutdoorLad Sam.

Title: Leisure Cycle to Monton
Summary:
Join Paul on this leisurely social bike ride starting from Central Manchester.
The 17 mile circular route starts with a brief venture through the heart of the City Centre, passing the Palace Theatre, the iconic Central Library and the Opera House on our way to Salford Central station via Spinningfields. Next, we will head out past Salford Cathedral and Salford University to discover the safer cycling route that runs along the busy East Lancs Road towards Worsley.
The route then follows a former railway loopline to Monton, where we have the option of a pub/snack stop.¬†Finally, we will join the Bridgewater Canal which takes us past the Trafford Centre and Old Trafford all the way back to the city centre.
Pace and Terrain
This will be a leisurely ride, suitable for all levels of fitness. We'll aim to maintain a steady pace of around 10mph. ¬†The route is relatively flat with level surfaces, apart from a few short, cobbled bits. Suitable for any roadworthy bike. Please make sure your bike is in good condition - check the tyres are well inflated, chain is oiled, and you've got a spare inner tube, drinks and snacks¬†with you.
The first part of the ride includes roads, but once out of the city centre we have the option of using shared cycle/footpaths and cycle/bus lanes which offer protection from the traffic. The second part of the ride, once we are on the loopline is almost all off road, There's just a short on-road stretch where we will have to leave and rejoin the Bridgewater Canal to cross the Barton Road Swing Bridge.
Photos
taken by the ride leader and used with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: A gentle leisure cycle

Title: Manchester LGBTQ+ History Walk
Summary:
Join us during LGBTQ+ History Month on a walking tour around the centre of Manchester to hear about the people, places, and moments that have shaped queer life in the city!
From learning about queer men‚Äôs meeting places in the 1780s, through to Victorian drag balls to the founding of the Campaign for Homosexual Equality, the rise of Canal Street, and the ongoing fight for equality, Manchester‚Äôs LGBTQ+ history is long, proud and defiant.
It‚Äôs always been queer up north and Manchester has been at the heart of LGBTQ+ culture for a long time.¬† Manchester¬†has¬†a¬†rich¬†and¬†vibrant¬†queer¬†history, and local events have played out in the context of cultural and legal changes in society at large. Our whistlestop tour shares some highlights of the last quarter millennium of Manchester‚Äôs queer history.
Manchester‚Äôs iconic Gay Village may be the beating heart of the LGBTQ+ community but there‚Äôs plenty of queer history and culture to see and hear about, in addition to Canal Street.
Our walking tour takes a circuit through the city centre of around 3 miles / 5 kilometres.¬† It‚Äôs pavement walking so comfortable footwear is recommended together with warm / waterproof clothing, depending on the weather!
Dogs
: well-behaved dogs may come on the walk, but must be on a lead and under close control at all times.
Waitlist
: if this event is fully booked and you want to come, add yourself to the wait list because places usually become available closer to the date.¬† This event will be repeated in the future.
Photo credits
: photos by ODL members with permission given to OutdoorLads for their use.
Difficulty & Distance: Distance of around 3 miles / 5 kilometres on pavements

Title: My favourite Art Deco buildings and other gems. Part I
Summary:
Back by popular demand! Having led these last year, a number of guys asked for me to repeat them. Look out for Part II on 28 March and Part III on 11 April.
Waitlist:¬†If this event is fully booked, but you'd like to attend,¬†please add yourself to the waitlist. Places often become available closer to the date
.
Join me as we take a trip around central London exploring my favourite Art Deco buildings and other architectural delights along the way. I'm by no means an expert, but I do love Art Deco and different styles of architecture and I will endeavour to provide some background about each building from my own research. We'll also pass a number of historic monuments and other notable places of interest.
Walking route and itinerary
This is a
linear walk
starting at London Bridge Station and ending near Blackfriars rail and underground stations.
This
route map
can be viewed in OS Maps, but is for guidance only. The exact route may differ slightly on the day due to construction work.
After a short introduction to the different Art Deco architectural styles, our first building is directly opposite us -
St Olaf House
(1928)
. We'll have a look at its inscriptions and ornate entrance before making our way to London Bridge via Queens Walk. Crossing the River Thames we'll stop to admire the view of the City of London and look back at Hayes Wharf. Our second Art Deco building is
Adelaide House
(1925)
, which is currently undergoing renovation. Photos will be shown.
Next we pass the
Monument
(1671)
, then head up onto Eastcheap to admire the many different architectural styles, with the
Walkie-Talkie or 20 Fenchchurch Street
building dominating the skyline. We'll pass Tower Hill Station and view a section of the
Roman London Wall
tucked behind a hotel. Our third Art Deco building is the spectacular
Ibex House
(1937)
. We'll then pass a number of skyscrapers in the City and make our way to the imposing
Guildhall
(1411)
,
via the Bank of England.
After a short walk, we arrive at
The Barbican
Estate
(1965)
, where we can stop for about an hour to have some lunch, you can view the
current exhibition
or visit the conservatory or walk around this unique brutalist estate.
Our fourth Art Deco masterpiece is
Florin Court
(1936)
in the historic Charterhouse Square, before we head past Smithfield Market towards ¬†Farringdon Street. After navigating around a construction site we pass through some secluded alleyways to Fleet Street. Our fifth and sixth Art Deco buildings are the former
Daily Telegraph
(1928)
(currently under some scaffolding) and
Daily Express (
1930)
buildings
.
Note there's not much room to stand here due to the major construction works opposite, so take care.
The final part of the walk takes us to the Embankment, where we can admire our seventh and final Art Deco building the
Oxo Tower (
1928
)
and Sea Containers House across the river. It's then a 2 min walk to Blackfriars train and underground station.
Afterwards
Optional local drinks at the Retro bar or in Soho for anyone who wishes to join me.
New Members
New members are very welcome. Please message me if you have any questions or concerns before the day.
All Images were taken by Neil Prior.
Difficulty & Distance: Flat, easy terrain 8km/5 miles on pavements and paths.

Title: Indoor Climbing Evening in Aberdeen
Summary:
A sociable evening to do some climbing on the indoor walls at Transition Extreme, Aberdeen Beach.
Suitable for beginners and experienced climbers alike. I can supervise two beginners. If more experienced climbers become available we can open up more places, so feel free to join the waitlist/drop me a message and I will get in touch. Its a great opportunity to start on some technically simple climbs with the safety of a top rope, and you can progress to more difficult climbs when you feel comfortable.
A climbing harness and rock shoes can be hired from the venue if you do not have your own. Helmets are optional.
Photos
: Adrian Rose
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Want to keep in touch with what's going on¬†in Scotland?
Join our Telegram
chat
and
notification
groups and bookmark our upcoming events list via our
Scottish Calendar
.
Difficulty & Distance: Suitable for beginners and experienced climbers alike.

Title: Formby Point
Summary:
Join Justin on this stunning beach¬†walk around Formby on Lancashire's West Coast.
We will take in the the beach, sand dunes and weave our way through¬†the coast forest on this diverse¬†day walk.
The Sefton coast home to red squirrels natterjack toads, sand lizards as well as other interesting flora and fauna.
The walk is flat and about
10
miles
long. I would give up to 6 hours to complete the walk
This is a dog friendly walk, so well behaved¬†dogs welcome.
We will call into a pub near the end .
All photos taken by walk leader
Difficulty & Distance: Long walk on mostly sand which can be energy sapping

Title: LONDON BOULDERING Thursday Evening - Beginners Welcome! üòÉ
Summary:
Come and join OutdoorLads for some bouldering in central London!
This event is for members of all levels of experience and all are welcome to come along to any of the sessions.
Bouldering is a form of climbing where instead of long high routes, the 'problems', as they are referred to, tend to be shorter and focus on technique, balance, body positioning and sometimes power. Because of this different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, harnesses and belaying, which makes the activities excellent for newcomers to the sport.
If you're a seasoned climber you won't need convincing about the benefits of bouldering, but for those who've never climbed more than a staircase, the benefits are wide ranging: from the physical - improved strength, tone, balance, power and coordination; mental - problem solving, focus, concentration and body awareness; to the emotional - relaxation, a sense of achievement and a feeling that mind and body are working together perfectly ('feeling psyched'). On top of all this, bouldering tends to be a very social sport where you can hang out with mates and each have a go as you feel regardless of what level you climb at.
Do I need a guided session?
If you have never tried bouldering before it is recommended that you have a guided session from the event leader, who will go through everything you will need to know to boulder safely before joining in with the rest of the group.
All those attending the event must also be aware of the centre's own terms and conditions of participation and abide by them, along with any instructions given by the centre‚Äôs staff. Everyone must also take responsibility for their own safety while participating in Indoor climbing events.
Independent boulderer?
As above all attending the event¬† must abide by the centre's T&Cs etc. As an experienced boulderer you are at all times responsible¬† for your own safety actions and involvement. As such, you should use your own judgement in taking up advice given either by OutdoorLads Volunteers or other experienced climbers.
Can't make this event?
We run weekly climbing and bouldering¬†events in the South East, so why not check out¬†what's coming up near you¬†here:
http://outdoorlads.events/SouthEastIndoorClimbing
. Alternatively, stay updated on upcoming events using the social media channels below:
Telegram
(Climbing and bouldering only):
OutdoorLads (SE) Climbing
Facebook:
http://fb.com/OutdoorLadsSouthEast
Twitter:
@OdlSouthEast
IMPORTANT! -¬†Participation Statement
You¬†MUST¬†complete a
Participation Statement
,
in addition
to booking your event space¬†before¬†attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Difficulty & Distance: With climbs at every grade from complete beginner to seasoned pro, you decide how hard it gets!

If you have never tried bouldering before it is recommended that you have a guided session from the event leader, who will go through everything you will need to know to boulder safely before joining in with the rest of the group.
All those attending the event must also be aware of the centre's own terms and conditions of participation and abide by them, along with any instructions given by the centre‚Äôs staff. Everyone must also take responsibility for their own safety while participating in Indoor climbing events.
Independent boulderer?
As above all attending the event¬† must abide by the centre's T&Cs etc. As an experienced boulderer you are at all times responsible¬† for your own safety actions and involvement. As such, you should use your own judgement in taking up advice given either by OutdoorLads Volunteers or other experienced climbers.
Can't make this event?
We run weekly climbing and bouldering¬†events in the South East, so why not check out¬†what's coming up near you¬†here:
http://outdoorlads.events/SouthEastIndoorClimbing
. Alternatively, stay updated on upcoming events using the social media channels below:
Telegram
(Climbing and bouldering only):
OutdoorLads (SE) Climbing
Facebook:
http://fb.com/OutdoorLadsSouthEast
Twitter:
@OdlSouthEast
IMPORTANT! -¬†Participation Statement
You¬†MUST¬†complete a
Participation Statement
,
in addition
to booking your event space¬†before¬†attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Difficulty & Distance: With climbs at every grade from complete beginner to seasoned pro, you decide how hard it gets!

Title: The Humber Hobble
Summary:
Join us for a fantastic walk from Hull to Hessle along the banks of the river Humber.
Along the way (weather permitting) expect to see some of the great views the River Humber has to offer, including the local wildlife and Humberside's most iconic structure The Humber Bridge. Connecting East Yorkshire to North Lincolnshire, the bridge has dominated the landscape for over 40 years.
We will stop at Hessle Foresore, right underneath the Humber Bridge, for a spot of lunch at the Country Park with fantastic views out over the Humber and some great photo opportunities.
Once lunch is finished we will head back the way we came to return to the start location.
Please note this walk is an 11 mile round trip on flat, easy paths and trails. If you don't fancy doing the full 11 miles, there is an option to get the bus back from Hessle to Hull after lunch.
So why not come along and join us to take in some good coastal fresh air in the company of great people! Just what we all need before a night out on the tiles at the
Hull Social
!
Difficulty & Distance: Flat route along paths and trails -  11 miles

Title: BIRMINGHAM Indoor Climbing - MONDAY - Experienced
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads for an evening at Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre.
"EXPERIENCED" in this instance is those that have previously climbed & can answer YES to all three of these questions:
Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
Can you tie in to a rope using the correct knots?
Can you belay another climber correctly &¬†confidently?
Please ensure you only sign up for this event if you
satisfy all three of the prerequisites as an experienced (independent) climber!
Never climbed before? Need a refresher on the basics? Answered NO to any of the three questions above? You will need to
attend one of the beginners (supervised) events
instead, where we will happily sign you in to be supervised (two people per leader maximum), show you the ropes & teach you everything you need to know to climb safely! Beginner (supervised) events are not offered every week.
Bouldering
- Most of us do roped climbing, but if you prefer to do bouldering, you can sign yourself in & go bouldering (unsupervised) instead of, or as well as, roped climbing. Please meet the leader & the group at the start though; some others might wish to do bouldering too!
Please note that we will not teach lead climbing or lead belaying on this event -
we would suggest having some
lessons in Lead Climbing
by a qualified member of staff if this is something you're interested in pursuing!
Whilst this event finishes at 8pm, the centre is open until 10pm if you wish to continue climbing for longer!
If you are subsequently unable to attend, please cancel off the event as 'no-shows' are frustrating for the leader & other attendees.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
Indoor climbing centres offer the challenges of climbing that you'll find on natural rock crags - simply indoors! It's a fun way to stay fit, make new friends & develop your climbing skills.
Climbing
- Unlike Indoor Bouldering there is a certain amount of skill to be mastered, such as tying in knots & belaying a partner, as well as the climbs being higher than in bouldering. If you are new to climbing or would like a refresher, then this is just for you!! If you‚Äôve climbed before, can safely tie into a harness & can competently belay, then there‚Äôs plenty of choices of top-rope & lead climbing on offer here.
Bouldering
-¬†Instead of tackling long high routes, the 'problems' (as they are referred to) are shorter & focus on technique, balance, body positioning & sometimes power.¬†With the different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, so it‚Äôs excellent (but not necessarily easier) for newcomers.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
has more than 75 lines with over 300 routes, set through some spectacular ground including its notorious 'stalactite'. It even features one of the few indoor 'Yorkshire VS cracks' in the country, to test your jamming skills. The¬†bouldering rooms are just as interesting as its climbing routes, over 200 bouldering problems have been organised into graded circuits to provide something for everyone.
You MUST register via this event page before coming to the centre!
To climb, you will need to:
Complete a

(please arrive early to do this in-person the first time) & pay a Registration Fee:

is

or

is

Entry Fee
directly to the climbing centre:
Standard Entry
is
¬£12.50
&
Bouldering Only
is
¬£8.50.
Hire
climbing shoes (
¬£3.50
) & a climbing harness (
¬£3.50
) if you don't own your own.
Please see Redpoint's
website
for current prices & note that prices are subject to change.
If you have any questions or need any more information just get in touch with the event leader by clicking on their profile below, or take a look at the
My first climbing event page

Title: An Evening with the Sheffield Symphony Orchestra
Summary:
Join us for an evening of culture at All Saints Church Ecclesall with the Sheffield Symphony Orchestra, featuring our very own Andy Ling on the viola.
Guest conductor:
Jason Thornton
-
Jason Thornton is the Music Director of Bath Philharmonia. He has conducted orchestras throughout the UK, Europe, America and the Far East, including the RPO, London Mozart Players, City of London Sinfonia, Beijing Symphony Orchestra, Jykasyla Sinfonia (Finland) and the Kaposvar Symphony Orchestra (Hungary).
Piano Soloist:
Jeneba Kanneh-Mason
-
Jeneba was a Keyboard Category Finalist in BBC Young Musician 2018, winner of the Murs du Son Prize at the Lagny-Sur-Marne International Piano Competition in France, 2014, and The Nottingham Young Musician 2013. She was also winner of the Iris Dyer Piano Prize at The Royal Academy of Music, Junior Academy, where she studied with Patsy Toh.
Beethoven‚Äôs 3rd piano concerto
His first in a minor key, also seen as a bridge between the Classical period governed by structure and form, and the Romantic which spoke to the heart and depicted emotions. At the premiere in 1803, Beethoven's page turner almost had a heart attack when he turned the page during the performance and the score was empty - Beethoven hadn't yet gone completely deaf (but had lost about 60% at this point) and was playing the solo part from memory.
Dvorak - Symphony no. 8 in G major
Apparently reminiscent of a summer's day in the country, with rustic melodies to get you dancing, birdsong and even a thunderstorm.
Wagner - Prelude to Act III of Lohengrin
Act 3 of Lohengrin is when the wedding takes place. However, as with all opera, it's not over till the fat lady sings and there is lots of tension and tears to come before the final curtain falls.
Tickets can be purchased online
on the SSO website
an will also be available on the door. The cost is ¬£18.50.
We will go for a drink at a nearby pub after the concert.

Title: Waterfalls, Caves and Lime kiln
Summary:
Join us for a 15km walk from Settle to Stainforth, exploring some of Yorkshire's hidden gems. Our adventure begins in the charming market town of Settle. As we head east, we‚Äôll visit Scaleber Force waterfall, nestled in a beautiful wooded ravine. The cascading waters run over limestone steps create a picturesque setting, perfect for photography enthusiasts.
Next, we'll head around Sugar Loaf Hill to explore the intriguing Victoria and Jubilee caves, rich with fascinating limestone formations and historical significance. These caves offer a unique glimpse into the area's geological and human past. Continuing our journey, we‚Äôll discover Catrigg Force, a secluded waterfall in a tranquil woodland glade. The twin plunges of water provide a peaceful spot to relax and appreciate nature's beauty.
As we approach Stainforth, we'll then encounter the Hoffman Kilns, remnants of the region's industrial heritage. These towering structures, once used for lime burning, stand as a testament to the area's history. This walk is a perfect blend of natural beauty and historical intrigue, making it an ideal walk. Join us and experience the wonders of the Yorkshire Dales!
When we finish we can grab a brew and cake from the Naked Man Cafe.
(All photographs taken by the walk leader and with permission to use)
Difficulty & Distance: Well marked paths and tracks, 15km  400m height gain.

Title: Pateley Bridge to Brimham Rocks
Summary:
This moderate 13km circular walk starts and finishes in Pateley Bridge. The walk from Pateley Bridge to Brimham Rocks is a scenic journey through the heart of Nidderdale blending riverside paths, open moorland, and expansive countryside views. Setting out from the charming market town, the route climbs steadily onto higher ground of rolling fields and moorland. We will stop for lunch at Brimham Rocks, where dramatic, weather-sculpted gritstone formations emerge unexpectedly from the moor, providing a striking and memorable contrast to the gentle landscapes encountered along the way. The walk returns to Pateley Bridge along the River Nidd.
Photo Credit: Brimham Rocks - JCW1967 (Flickr) Creative Commons License; Pateley Bridge- Tom Blackwell (Flickr) Creative Commons License;
Difficulty & Distance: 400m climb, expect mud.

Title: BIG20: Winter Camp (Day events and social only)
Summary:
Join Outdoors as we celebrate our
20th Birthday
at Winter Camp in the heart of the Lakes District, back to where it all began in 2006. ¬†Whether you have been around since that time or joined us recently, all are welcome. Winter Camp was OutdoorLads' first EVER event back in 2006 and the perfect place to kick off our year of celebratory events! This year we are making it bigger and better than ever, with a choice of tents, pods, campervans or a hostel to bring together as many members as possible to launch the celebrations!
This event page
DOES NOT INCLUDE ANY ACCOMMODATION
.
It is for those coming for the activities only - walks and the Saturday evening social
event at a local pub, which includes dinner. Hence this page is for those who live locally, or have booked your own accommodation separately.
With the towering Langdale Pikes looming above it, our campsite is a particularly dramatic spot to pitch up for an adventure in the outdoors. The award-winning site offers a wide selection of grassy pitches as well as a collection of wooden camping pods. It boasts two newly upgraded toilet and shower blocks, washing-up areas, a laundry and drying room.
The name should give it away, but this is camping in the winter and so it will be cold! While it's not for the faint hearted, equally it's not out of reach of anyone. It goes without saying that you'll need to make good preparations to keep warm and dry all weekend, but having done that, you'll find that winter camping can be a great experience. Think mountain view, cold, and if you're lucky some snow, but also think roaring fires in great pubs with hearty food, good conversation with new and old friends, all making a memorable weekend.
On the Saturday there'll be a range of walk and activity options of varying difficulties. They will vary depending on the conditions at the time, but in this part of the country, every walk is a stunner and there are lots of options - very likely there will be a harder mountain walk and something a bit easier, but there will still be lots of ascent involved - this is the Lake District after all.
On the Sunday we hope you'll stay around for another, shorter walk. We aim to be finished around mid-afternoon.
Depending on the conditions, there may also be the opportunity to learn/improve your winter walking skills as we have three great winter walking leaders on hand to share their knowledge and experience.
Our campsite has great onsite facilities including a cafe serving early morning breakfast snacks and some truly great showers which are free to use, heated by the onsite Biomass boiler. Truly environmentally friendly!¬†You will need to provide your own food EXCEPT for Saturday evening, as that meal is included in the price!
Birthday Celebrations
On the Saturday evening at we plan to visit a nearby pub who are preparing us dinner, and a private space for a bit of a social evening. ¬†The food is included in the event price, and there are options provided for those with dietary requirements, don't worry! (You will need to have your dietary requirements up to date on the event page please, or we cant guarantee to be able to cater for different needs on the night.) ¬†Obviously drinks are at your own cost that night.
This is a great chance to relax with your OutdoorLads friends, reminisce over the last 20 years, ¬†laugh about the good times, the bad fancy dress decisions and the challenging climbs!
Dogs
: Well behaved dogs are welcome, must remain on a lead on site and owners will need to clean up after them. Dogs listed under the Dangerous Dogs Act 1991 are not permitted at National Trust campsites.
Photos:
Taken by event leaders and used by OutdoorLads with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Winter weather likely, but we will aim to offer a range of walks.
